revision.text:
'''Vaccination and religion''' have interrelations of varying kinds. Almost no religions object to vaccination,<ref name="slate">{{Cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/medical_examiner/2015/02/religious_exemption_for_vaccines_christian_scientists_catholics_and_dutch.html |title=Why Is There a Religious Exemption for Vaccinations? |last=Krule |first=Miriam |work=Slate}}</ref> and some parents either fake religious adherence<ref name="cbs-fake">{{Cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/parents-fake-religion-to-avoid-vaccines/ |title=Parents Fake Religion To Avoid Vaccines |date=October 17, 2007 |work=CBS News / AP}}</ref> or invent fake religions to provide exemption.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/health/antivaccination-group-encourages-parents-to-join-fake-church-20150127-12zcrc.html |title=Anti-vaccination group encourages parents to join fake church |last=Medew |first=Julia |date=2015-01-28 |work=Sydney morning Herald}}</ref>
== Historical ==
The influential Massachusetts preacher [[Cotton Mather]] was the first known person to attempt [[smallpox]] [[inoculation]] on a large scale, inoculating himself and over 200 members of his congregation with the help of a local doctor. While his view became standard, he also caused the first reaction against the practice.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
[[Rowland Hill (preacher)|Rowland Hill]] (1744–1833) was a popular English preacher acquainted with [[Edward Jenner]], the pioneer of smallpox [[vaccination]], and he encouraged the vaccination of the congregations he visited or preached to.<ref name="Bazin2000">{{cite book|author=H. Bazin|title=The eradication of smallpox: Edward Jenner and the first and only eradication of a human infectious disease|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8bPuAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA75|date=19 January 2000|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=978-0-12-083475-4|pages=75–}}</ref> He published a tract on the subject in 1806,<ref name="GlynnGlynn2004">{{cite book|author1=Ian Glynn|author2=Jenifer Glynn|title=The Life and Death of Smallpox|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tL4W3YNMYLIC&pg=PA112|date=30 August 2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-84542-7|pages=112–}}</ref> at a time when many medical men refused to sanction it. Later he became a member of the Royal Jennererian Society, which was established when vaccination was accepted in Britain, India, the US, and elsewhere. [[John C. Lettsom]], an eminent [[Religious Society of Friends|Quaker]] physician of the day wrote to Rowland Hill commenting:
: "You have done more good than you imagine; and for everyone you may have saved by your actual operation, you have saved ten by your example; and perhaps, next to [[Edward Jenner|Jenner]], have been the means of saving more lives than any other individual."<ref name="Rhodes2013">{{cite book|author=John Rhodes|title=The End of Plagues: The Global Battle Against Infectious Disease|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hdRWAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT50|date=24 September 2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-38131-6|pages=50–}}</ref>
Several [[Boston]] clergymen and devout physicians formed a society that opposed vaccination in 1798.<ref>David P. Mindell, The Evolving World: Evolution in Everyday Life (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 2007 [2006]), p. 10</ref> Others complained that the practice was dangerous, going so far as to demand that doctors who carried out these procedures be tried for attempted murder.<ref>{{cite book |chapter= Theological opposition to inoculation, vaccination, and the use of anæsthetics |title= A History of the Warfare of Science with Theology in Christendom |author= Andrew Dickson White |publisher=Appleton |year= 1896 |chapterurl=http://abob.libs.uga.edu/bobk/whitem10.html |accessdate=2007-08-17}}</ref>
In 1816 Iceland made the clergy responsible for smallpox vaccination and gave them the responsibility of keeping vaccination records for their parishes; Sweden also had similar practices.<ref>{{cite book |author= Pétursson P |year=1983 |title= Church and Social Change: A Study of the Secularization Process in Iceland, 1830–1930 |series= Studies in religious experience and behaviour, nr. 4 |location= Helsingborg, Sweden |publisher= Plus Ultra |pages= 70, 79 |isbn=91-970355-9-9}}</ref>
When vaccination was introduced into [[United Kingdom|UK]] public policy, and adoption followed overseas, there was opposition from trade unionists and others, including sectarian ministers and those interested in self-help and alternative medicines like homeopathy.<ref>Durbach, Nadja. 2005. ''Bodily matters: the anti-vaccination movement in England, 1853–1907''. Radical perspectives. Durham: Duke University Press. pp 40–45.</ref>
[[Anti-vaccinationists]] were most common in Protestant countries. Those who were religious often came from minority religious movements outside of mainstream Protestantism, including Quakers in England and Baptists in Sweden.<ref>Bourdelais, Patrice. 2006.'' Epidemics laid low: a history of what happened in rich countries.'' Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. pp. 25–26.</ref>
Catholic and Anglican missionaries vaccinated Northwest Coast Native Americans during an 1862 smallpox epidemic.<ref>{{Cite book |author= Boyd RW | title=The Coming of the Spirit of Pestilence: Introduced Infectious Diseases and Population Decline Among Northwest Coast Indians, 1774–1874 | year=1999 | publisher= University of Washington Press | location=Seattle |isbn=0-295-97837-6 |chapter= A final disaster: the 1862 smallpox epidemic in coastal British Columbia |pages=172–201}}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], a number of [[Vaccination Acts]] were introduced to control vaccination and inoculation, starting in 1840, when [[variolation|smallpox inoculation]] was banned. The 1853 Act introduced compulsory free infant vaccination enforced by local authorities. By 1871, infant vaccination was compulsory and parents refusing to have their child vaccinated were fined and imprisoned if the fines were not paid. Resistance to compulsion grew, and in 1889, after riots in [[Leicester]], a Royal Commission was appointed and issued six reports between 1892 and 1896. It recommended the abolition of cumulative penalties. This was done in an 1898 Act, which also introduced a conscience clause that exempted parents who did not believe vaccination was efficacious or safe. This extended the concept of the "[[conscientious objector]]" in English law. <!-- see Talk and Hansard-->A further Act in 1907 made it easier to obtain exemption.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
[[Jehovah's Witnesses]] banned their members from receiving vaccinations from 1931 to 1952. They have since reversed their position. The decision of whether to vaccinate themselves or their family is left to the individual Witness. Some more recent Jehovah's Witness publications have mentioned the success of vaccination programs.<ref>[http://www.religioustolerance.org/witness6.htm About the Jehovah's Witnesses Christian denomination - Past opposition to vaccinations], religioustolerance.org</ref>
== Current ==
[[Christian Science]] selectively rejects various forms of medical care including vaccination.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nj.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2014/11/9000_nj_school_children_skipped_vaccinations_on_religious_grounds.html|title=Nearly 9,000 N.J. school children skipped vaccinations on religious grounds last year|author= Livio, Susan K|accessdate=2015-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00031788.htm|title=Outbreak of Measles Among Christian Science Students – Missouri and Illinois, 1994|accessdate=2015-03-11}}</ref> The Congregation of Universal Wisdom, a religion based on belief in [[spinal adjustment|chiropractic spinal adjustments]] and [[Spirit of Guidance|Universal Intelligence]], forbids vaccinations.<ref name=CUW>{{Citation |date= |title=Congregation of Universal Wisdom |publisher=Congregation of Universal Wisdom |url=http://www.cuwisdom.org/ |accessdate=April 11, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=Kellner>{{Citation |last=Kellner |first=Mark |date=February 7, 2015 |title='Religious' objections to vaccinations? There really aren't any |publisher=''[[Deseret News]]'' |url=http://national.deseretnews.com/article/3483/religious-objections-to-vaccinations-there-really-arent-any.html |accessdate=April 11, 2015 }}</ref> The ''New York Times'' covered the Congregation of Universal Wisdom and noted that many families have used these religious memberships to avoid vaccination requirements.<ref name=McNeil>{{Citation |last=McNeil, Jr. |first=Donald |date=January 14, 2003 |title=Worship Optional: Joining a Church To Avoid Vaccines |publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/14/science/worship-optional-joining-a-church-to-avoid-vaccines.html |accessdate=April 11, 2015 }}</ref> In a court case citing the Congregation of Universal Wisdom, ''Turner v. Liverpool Cent. School'', the United States District Court in New York affirmed the permissibility of claiming religious exemption from vaccination on the basis of such membership.<ref>''[https://casetext.com/case/turner-v-liverpool-central-sch-bd-of-education#idm515056-fn4 Turner v. Liverpool Cent. School, 186 F. Supp.2d 187 (N.D.N.Y. 2002)]''</ref>
Some conservative Christian groups in the United States oppose mandatory vaccination for diseases typically spread via sexual contact, arguing that the possibility of disease deters risky sexual contact. For example, the [[Family Research Council]] opposes mandatory [[HPV vaccine|vaccination against HPV]], a virus that causes various cancers,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/hpv.html|title=Pinkbook - HPV - Epidemiology of Vaccine Preventable Diseases - CDC|website=www.cdc.gov}}</ref> writing, "Our primary concern is with the message that would be delivered to nine- to 12-year-olds with the administration of the vaccines. Care must be taken not to communicate that such an intervention makes all sex 'safe'."<ref>{{cite news |author= Danny Fortson |title= Moral majority take on GSK and Merck over cancer drugs |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/moral-majority-take-on-gsk-and-merck-over-cancer-drugs-481844.html |accessdate=2006-11-02 |date=2006-06-11 |work= The Independent |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/14/AR2006071401532.html |title= Pro-family, pro-vaccine – but keep it voluntary |author= Sprigg P |work= Washington Post |date=2006-07-15 |accessdate=2008-06-15}}</ref> Studies have shown that HPV vaccination does not result in increased sexual activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/pages/HPV-Vaccination-Does-Not-Lead-to-Increased-Sexual-Activity.aspx|title=HPV Vaccination Does Not Lead to Increased Sexual Activity|website=www.aap.org}}</ref>
[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] has made vaccination an official initiative in its humanitarian relief program.<ref>{{cite web|last=The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|title=Church Makes Immunizations an Official Initiative, Provides Social Mobilization|url=http://www.lds.org/church/news/church-makes-immunizations-an-official-initiative-provides-social-mobilization|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref> The Church has also called on its members to see that their own children are properly vaccinated.<ref>[http://www.lds.org/liahona/1978/07/immunize-children-leaders-urge "Immunize Children, Leaders Urge"], ''[[Liahona (magazine)|Liahona]]'', July 1978 (accessed 2 August 2012).</ref>
[[Islam]] and [[Judaism]], religions with dietary prohibitions that regard particular animals as unclean, make exceptions for medical treatments derived from those animals.<ref>{{cite web |vauthors=Mynors G, Ghalamkari H, Beaumont S, Powell S, McGee P |url=http://www.npci.org.uk/therapeutics/cardio/diabetes1/resources/library_other_publications_drugs_of_porcine_origin.pdf |title=Drugs of porcine origin and their clinical alternatives: an introductory guide |format=PDF |publisher= National Prescribing Centre |year=2004 |accessdate=2009-05-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.immunize.org/concerns/porcine.pdf |format=PDF |title= (Form letter EDB.7/3 P6/61/3) |publisher= World Health Organization, Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean |date=2001-07-17 |author=Gezairy HA |accessdate=2009-05-12}}</ref>
In [[Aceh Province]], an autonomous province of [[Indonesia]] with its own Islamic Sharia Law, 80 percent of people refuse all vaccinations due to concerns about pig, or its derivatives, being used to make some vaccines (eating pig is considered [[haram]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tribunnews.com/regional/2015/05/03/80-persen-warga-aceh-anggap-imunisasi-haram-ini-alasannya |title=80 Persen Warga Aceh Anggap Imunisasi Haram, Ini Alasannya |author=Hasanudin Aco |date=April 3, 2015}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}<!---an English-language citation would be nice--->
The use of [[fetal tissue in vaccines|fetal tissue in the development of vaccines]] has also provoked some controversy among religions opposed to [[abortion]]. The cell culture media of some viral vaccines, and the virus of the [[rubella]] vaccine, are derived from tissues taken from therapeutic abortions performed in the 1960s, leading to moral questions. For example, the [[principle of double effect]], originated by [[Thomas Aquinas]], holds that actions with both good and bad consequences are morally acceptable in specific circumstances, and the question is how this principle applies to vaccination.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.immunizationinfo.org/assets/files/pdfs/Moral_Considerations_With_Certain_Viral_Vaccines.pdf |format=PDF |title= Moral considerations with certain viral vaccines |author= Grabenstein JD |journal= Christ Pharm |issn=1094-9534 |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=3–6 |year=1999 |accessdate=2009-05-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The Vatican Curia has expressed concern about the rubella vaccine's embryonic cell origin, saying Catholics have "...a grave responsibility to use alternative vaccines and to make a conscientious objection with regard to those which have moral problems."<ref name=Vatican>{{cite journal |author= Pontifical Academy for Life |title= Moral reflections on vaccines prepared from cells derived from aborted human foetuses |year= 2005 |journal= Medicina e Morale |publisher= Center for Bioethics, Catholic University of the Sacred Heart |url= http://www.academiavita.org/template.jsp?sez=Documenti&pag=testo/vacc/vacc&lang=english |accessdate= 2008-12-03 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060507072740/http://www.academiavita.org/template.jsp?sez=Documenti&pag=testo%2Fvacc%2Fvacc&lang=english |archivedate= 2006-05-07 |df= }}</ref> The Vatican concluded that until an alternative becomes available it is acceptable for [[Catholic]]s to use the existing vaccine, writing, "This is an unjust alternative choice, which must be eliminated as soon as possible."<ref name=Vatican/>
===Political opposition to vaccination by religious groups===
The majority of Orthodox Rabbis view vaccination as a religious obligation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ou.org/news/statement-vaccinations-ou-rabbinical-council-america/|title=Statement on Vaccinations from the OU and Rabbinical Council of America|publisher=Orthodox Union|date=2015-02-10|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> A magazine called P.E.A.C.H. that presented an anti-immunization message to Orthodox Jews was distributed in Brooklyn, New York in early 2014. This is not a widespread phenomenon though. 96% of students at Yeshivas (who are essentially all Orthodox Jewish) in New York City were immunized according to information obtained in 2014, although this is a lower than average rate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/articles/205801/are-ultra-orthodox-turning-away-from-vaccination/?p=all|title=Are Ultra-Orthodox Turning Away From Vaccination?|last=Nathan-Kazis|first=Josh|work=Forward|date=2014-09-17|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref>
In 2003 imams in northern [[Nigeria]] advised their followers not to have their children vaccinated with oral polio vaccine, perceived to be a plot by Westerners to decrease Muslim fertility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/29781528/ns/health-infectious_diseases/t/muslim-clerics-finally-embrace-polio-campaign/#.VQC3WIF4qcY|title=Muslim Clerics Finally Embrace Polio Campaign|accessdate=2015-03-11}}</ref> The boycott caused the number of polio cases to rise not only in Nigeria but also in neighboring countries. The followers were also wary of other vaccinations, and Nigeria reported over 20,000 measles cases and nearly 600 deaths from measles from January through March 2005.<ref name=Clements>{{cite journal |journal=Curr Drug Saf |volume=1 |issue=1 |year=2006 |pages=117–19 |title=How vaccine safety can become political – the example of polio in Nigeria |vauthors=Clements CJ, Greenough P, Shull D |url=http://bentham.org/cds/samples/cds1-1/Clements.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-07-28 |doi=10.2174/157488606775252575 |pmid=18690921 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928030913/http://bentham.org/cds/samples/cds1-1/Clements.pdf |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2006 Nigeria accounted for over half of all new polio cases worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wild poliovirus 2000–2008 |date=2008-02-05 |url=http://www.polioeradication.org/content/general/casecount.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Global Polio Eradication Initiative |accessdate=2008-02-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927204139/http://www.polioeradication.org/content/general/casecount.pdf |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Outbreaks continued thereafter; for example, at least 200 children died in a late-2007 measles outbreak in [[Borno State]].<ref>{{cite news |title= 'Hundreds' dead in measles outbreak |publisher=IRIN |date=2007-12-14 |url=http://irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=75883 |accessdate=2008-02-10}}</ref> In 2013, nine health workers administering polio vaccine were targeted and killed by gunmen on motorcycles in [[Kano]], but this was an isolated incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21381773|title=Polio vaccinators killed in Nigeria|date=8 February 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-33650543 | work=BBC News | title=Nigeria marks one year without recorded polio case | date=2015-07-24}}</ref> Local traditional and religious leaders and polio survivors worked to support the vaccination campaign,<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/23/us-health-polio-nigeria-idUSKCN0PX2RF20150723 | work=Reuters | title=Nigeria marks polio-free year, raising global eradication hopes | date=2015-07-23}}</ref> and Nigeria has not had a polio case since July 24, 2014; in 2017, if no new cases appear, Nigeria will be declared polio-free.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
In the 2000s, in [[Poliomyelitis in Pakistan|Pakistan]] and Afghanistan, some [[Taliban]] issued ''[[fatwa]]s'' opposing vaccination as an American plot to sterilize Muslims, and kidnapped, beat, and assassinated vaccination officials; the head of Pakistan's vaccination campaign in [[Bajaur Agency]] was assassinated in 2007, on his way back from a meeting with a religious leader.<ref name="nature.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110714/full/news.2011.418.html|title=Fake vaccination campaign raises real fears|last=Brumfiel|first=Geoff|work=Nature News|date=2011-07-14|accessdate=2017-03-14|doi=10.1038/news.2011.418}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Warraich HJ |title=Religious opposition to polio vaccination |journal=Emerg Infect Dis |volume=15 |issue=6 |doi=10.3201/eid1506.090087 |url=http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/articles/issue/15/6/table-of-contents|year=2009 |pages=978–78 |pmid=19523311 |pmc=2727330}}</ref> In 2011, a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] spy ran a fake hepatitis vaccination campaign to search for Osama bin Laden; such actions were strongly condemned by US<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/02/aid-groups-cia-osama-bin-laden-polio-crisis|title=CIA tactics to trap Bin Laden linked with polio crisis, say aid groups|last=Shah|first=Saeed|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2012-03-02|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> and international health [[NGO]]s,<ref name="nature.com"/> the doctor involved was jailed<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/23/doctor-bin-laden-cia-jail|title=Doctor who helped US in search for Osama Bin Laden jailed for 33 years|last=Boone|first=Jon|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2012-05-23|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> and the CIA promised not to use vaccination as a cover again.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2014/10/26/mistrust-and-polio-pakistan/xxBRaW1A6JnbkoKCeRdSSK/story.html|title=Mistrust and polio in Pakistan|last=Carroll|first=James|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=2014-10-27|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> A genuine polio vaccinator had previously vaccinated Osama bin Laden's children and grandchildren in his compound in Abbottabad.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/11/cia-fake-vaccinations-osama-bin-ladens-dna|title=CIA organised fake vaccination drive to get Osama bin Laden's family DNA|last=Shah|first=Saeed|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-07-11|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> Both major sides of the Afghani civil war now support polio vaccination,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-26121732 | work=BBC News | title=Afghanistan polio: First case in Kabul since 2001 | date=2014-02-11}}</ref> and polio rates are declining rapidly in Afghanistan, with only five cases in Jan–July 2015.<ref name="reuters.com"/> In [[Pakistan]] there were 28 cases in the same period.<ref name="reuters.com"/>
In 2015, leaders of the [[Nation of Islam]] spoke out against a California Bill that removed philosophical exemptions to school vaccination requirements.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nation Of Islam Leader Voices Opposition To Mandatory Vaccine Bill|url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2015/06/23/nation-of-islam-leader-voices-opposition-to-bill-that-would-require-public-school-students-to-be-immunized/|agency=CBS Los Angeles}}</ref> Saying that data suggests "that African American males who received the MMR vaccine before age 36 months were at increased risk for autism." They also said that that government mandated vaccines were another [[Tuskegee Syphilis Study]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Los Angeles|title=Nation of Islam opposes California vaccine mandate bill|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/political/la-me-pc-nation-of-islam-california-vaccine-mandate-bill-20150622-story.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref>
== Exemptions ==
In the U.S., all states except Mississippi, California and West Virginia allow parents to opt out of their children's otherwise-mandatory vaccinations for religious reasons. The number of religious exemptions rose greatly in the late 1990s and early 2000s; for example, in [[Massachusetts]], the rate of those seeking exemptions rose from 0.24% in 1996 to 0.60% in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1108/07363761111181464|title=Against medical advice: the anti-consumption of vaccines|date=|website=|publisher=The University of Auckland Business School, Auckland, New Zealand|access-date=22 March 2016}}</ref> Some parents falsely claim religious beliefs to get exemptions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-10-17-19819928_x.htm |date=2007-10-17 |accessdate=2007-11-24 |author= LeBlanc S |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |title= Parents use religion to avoid vaccines |work= USA Today}}</ref> The [[American Medical Association]] opposes such exemptions, saying that they endanger health not only for the unvaccinated individual but also for neighbors and the community at large.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ama-assn.org/ad-com/polfind/Hlth-Ethics.pdf |author= American Medical Association |title= Health and Ethics Policies of the AMA House of Delegates |quote= H-440.970 Religious Exemptions from Immunizations |format=PDF |pages=460–61 |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref>
On January 1, 2016 Australia introduced legislation that removed eligibility for childcare and welfare benefits if parents refuse to vaccinate their children, removing religious exemptions at the same time as the only religion to apply for an exemption (Church of Christ Science) deemed their exemption to no longer be relevant.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/no-jab-no-pay-reforms-religious-exemptions-for-vaccination-dumped/news-story/5941541520ab64a115704f58633a1d68 | title=religious exemption removed}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{commons category|Vaccination campaigns}}

revision.comment: /* Water resources */clean up spacing around commas, replaced: , → , using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[Image:SatparaLakeSkardu1215.jpg|thumb|The [[Satpara Lake]], a source of water supply for the town of [[Skardu]].]] '''[[Water resource]]s''' management in '''[[Pakistan]]'''.
==Water resources== According to the United Nations' "[[UN World Water Development Report]]", the total actual renewable water resources increased from 2,961 m³ per capita in 2000 to 3,420 m³ per capita in 2005. <ref>{{cite journal | last = United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) | authorlink = UNESCO | title = The 2nd UN World Water Development Report: 'Water, a shared responsibility' | date = March 2006 | url = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001454/145405E.pdf | isbn = 92-3-104006-5 | accessdate = 2008-05-28 | publisher = UNESCO | location = New York}}, p. 134</ref> A more recent study indicates an available supply of water of little more than 1,000 m³ per person, which puts Pakistan in the category of a high stress country. Using data from the Pakistani federal government's Planning and Development Division, the overall water availability has decreased from 1,299 m³ per capita in 1996-97 to 1,101 m³ per capita in 2004-05.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Government of Pakistan, Ministry of Economic Affairs and Statistics, Statistics Division | title = Overall Water Availability | journal = Pakistan Statistical Year Book 2007 | url = http://www.statpak.gov.pk/depts/fbs/publications/yearbook2007/agriculture/1.15.pdf | accessdate = 2008-06-06}} The figures were converted into m³ and then divided by the population of the respective year, using data from http://devdata.worldbank.org/query/</ref> In view of [[population growth|growing population]], [[urbanization]] and increased [[industrialization]], the situation is likely to get worse.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Ministry of Finance | authorlink = Ministry of Finance (Pakistan) | title = Pakistan Economic Survey 2006-07. Chapter 16: Environment | date = June 2007 | url = http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters/16-Environment.PDF | accessdate = 2008-05-28 | format = }}, p. 248</ref> Nevertheless, excessive mining of groundwater goes on. Despite a lowering [[water table]], the annual growth rate of electric [[Water well|tubewells]] has been indicated to 6.7% and for diesel tubewells to about 7.4%.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Asian Development Bank (ADB) | authorlink = Asian Development Bank | title = RRP: PAK 37135. Report and recommendation of the president to the board of directors on proposed loans and technical assistance grants to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Balochistan Resource Management Program | date = November 2004 | url = http://www.adb.org/Documents/RRPs/PAK/rrp-pak-37135.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-28}}, p. 11</ref> In addition, increasing pollution and [[saltwater intrusion]] threaten the country's water resources. About 36% of the [[groundwater]] is classified as highly saline.<ref>{{cite web | last = Pakistan Water Gateway | title = The Pakistan Water Situational Analysis | url = http://waterinfo.net.pk/pdf/pwsa.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-28}}, p. 4</ref>
In urban areas, most water is supplied from groundwater except for the cities of Karachi, and a part of Islamabad, where mainly surface water is used. In most rural areas, groundwater is used. In rural areas with saline groundwater, irrigation canals serve as the main source of domestic water.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Government of Pakistan. Ministry of Planning and Development | title = Medium Term Development Framework 2005-10. Section 10: Water and Sanitation | location = Islamabad | date = 2004 | url = http://www.pakistan.gov.pk/ministries/planninganddevelopment-ministry/mtdf/10-Water%20and%20Sanitation/10-Water%20&%20Sanitation.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090304173501/http://www.pakistan.gov.pk/ministries/planninganddevelopment-ministry/mtdf/10-Water%20and%20Sanitation/10-Water%20&%20Sanitation.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2009-03-04 | accessdate = 2008-05-29}}, section 10.2.</ref>
==Water use== Out of the 169,384 billion m³ of water which were withdrawn in 2000, 96% were used for agricultural purposes, leaving 2% for domestic and another 2% for industrial use.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bridges | first = Geoff |author2=Asian Development Bank (ADB) |authorlink2=Asian Development Bank | title = Asian Water Development Outlook 2007. Country Paper Pakistan | date = 2007 | url = http://www.adb.org/Documents/Books/AWDO/2007/cr08.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-28}}, p. 5</ref> By far most water is used for [[irrigation|irrigated]] agriculture, emphasizing the particular significance of agriculture in the country. The sector contributes about 25% of the Pakistan's [[GNP]] (2000-2001).<ref name="ADB 6">{{cite journal | last = Government of Pakistan. Ministry of Water and Power | authorlink = | title = Pakistan Water Sector Strategy. Executive Summary. Volume 1 | date = October 2002 | url = http://www.waterinfo.net.pk/pdf/vol1.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-29}}, p. 6</ref> The country still has the world's largest contiguous irrigation system.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Government of Pakistan. Ministry of Water and Power | authorlink = | title = Pakistan Water Sector Strategy. Executive Summary. Volume 1 | date = October 2002 | url = http://www.waterinfo.net.pk/pdf/vol1.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-29}}, p. 3</ref> In 1999-2000, the total irrigated area in Pakistan was 181,000 km².<ref>{{cite web | last = Pakistan Water Gateway | title = The Pakistan Water Situational Analysis | date = 2005 | url = http://waterinfo.net.pk/pdf/pwsa.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-28}}, p. 6</ref>
Water is also essential for [[power generation]] in Pakistan, since about 29% is generated through [[hydropower]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Pakistan Water Gateway | title = The Pakistan Water Situational Analysis | date = 2005 | url = http://waterinfo.net.pk/pdf/pwsa.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-28}}, p. 8-9</ref>
==See also== *[[Water supply and sanitation in Pakistan]]
==References== <ref>{{cite web|title=Pakistan Water Sector Strategy - Volume 1|url=http://www.waterinfo.net.pk/sites/default/files/knowledge/Pakistan%20Water%20Sector%20Strategy%20-%20Vol%201.pdf|publisher=Pakistan Water Gateway|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>
<ref>{{cite web|title=Pakistan Water Situation Analysis|url=http://www.waterinfo.net.pk/sites/default/files/knowledge/Pakistan%20Water%20Situation%20Analysis.pdf|publisher=Pakistan Water Gateway|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>
